poem:
**Unflagging Anthem**

Under dim lights, the skeptic's gasp  
gave way to chorused echoes vast.   
Whispers of doubt fell to the floor,  
as 130 million voices soared.  
Heartbeats in unison, defiance in song,   
we were wrong, we were wrong.  
In tattered dreams persist the brave,  
Les Misérables—beyond the grave.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Les Misérables: a musical full of heart and hope that continues to defy its critics So were we wrong? By “we” I mean the overnight critics, myself included, who gave largely negative reviews to the musical of Les Misérables when it opened at the Barbican in October 1985. All the statistics suggest we misjudged popular taste. Since it began the show has been seen by more than 130 million people, has played in 57 countries". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
